entry.et: Middle French attaquer, from Old Italian *estaccare to attach, from stacca stake, of Germanic origin; akin to Old English staca

def.dt: :to set upon or work against forcefully
:to assail with unfriendly or bitter words
:to begin to affect or to act on injuriously plants attacked by aphids
:to set to work on attack a problem
:to threaten (a piece in chess) with immediate capture
:to make an attack

entry.pt: attack assail assault bombard storm mean to make an onslaught upon. attack implies taking the initiative in a struggle plan to attack the town at dawn. assail implies attempting to break down resistance by repeated blows or shots assailed the enemy with artillery fire. assault suggests a direct attempt to overpower by suddenness and violence of onslaught commandos assaulted the building from all sides. bombard applies to attacking with bombs or shells bombarded the city nightly. storm implies attempting to break into a defended position preparing to storm the fortress.

def.dt: :the act of attacking with physical force or unfriendly words :assault
:a belligerent or antagonistic action
:a fit of sickness
:an active episode of a chronic or recurrent disease
:a period of being strongly affected by something (as a desire or mood)
:an offensive or scoring action won the game with an 8-hit attack
:offensive players or the positions taken up by them
:the setting to work on some undertaking made a new attack on the problem
:the beginning of destructive action (as by a chemical agent)
:the act or manner of beginning a musical tone or phrase
:designed, planned, or used for carrying out a military attack an attack helicopter
:a dog trained to attack on command or on sight
:a person noted for harsh, personal, and usually public verbal attacks against others a political attack dog
:the acute angle between the direction of the relative wind and the chord of an airfoil
:a mass attack by Japanese soldiers in World War II
:an all-out usually desperate attack
:stroke5

:an acute episode of heart disease marked by the death or damage of heart muscle due to insufficient blood supply to the heart usually as a result of a coronary thrombosis or a coronary occlusion and that is characterized especially by chest pain called also myocardial infarction
:an episode of intense fear or apprehension that is of sudden onset

:a brief episode of cerebral ischemia that is usually characterized by temporary blurring of vision, slurring of speech, numbness, paralysis, or syncope and is often predictive of a serious stroke abbreviation TIA called also ministroke
